column1: Kaukauna ( (listen)) is a city in Outagamie and Calumet counties
column3: United States. It is situated on the Fox River
column4: approximately 100 miles (160 km) north of Milwaukee. The population was 15
column5: 462 at the 2010 census. It is a part of the Appleton

column1: Kaukauna is a Native American word and in various languages means "portage"
column4: and "place of pike". This area was traditionally home to the Ho-Chunk and Menominee peoples. The first Europeans in the area were the French. The first Catholic missionary in the area
column6: commented on the "apple trees and vine stalks in abundance" that he found the people of Kaukauna cultivating. Kaukuana became an outpost of trade in Green Bay and saw much intermarriage between French and Menominee people
column7: leading to a Métis culture which produced local leaders such as Augustin Grignon.In 1836
column8: following years of negotiations about how to accommodate the Oneida
column10: and Brothertown peoples who were removed from New York
column11: the Menominee ceded over four million acres of land to the United States in the Treaty of the Cedars. Grignon of Kaukuana was one of the signatories of the treaty.Prior to 1880
column13: Kaukauna was known as "The Lion on the Fox". This nickname was changed to "The Electric City" upon the completion of the hydroelectric plant. When the city was incorporated in 1885
column14: it was separated from the adjacent rural parts of the town. The first recorded land deed in Wisconsin was assigned to Dominique Ducharme in 1793. He obtained 1
column15: 281 acres (518 ha) from the Menominee Indians for two barrels of rum and other gifts. These acres are the original site of the town of Kaukauna. The property was purchased by Charles A. Grignon (and recorded Dec. 18
column17: who built a mansion on the river on Kaukauna's north side. The home
column19: is operated as a museum by the Outagamie County Historical Society.

column1: Kaukauna is located in southeastern Outagamie County
column2: with a small portion extending south into Calumet County along State Highway 55 (Friendship Drive). According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 8.06 square miles (20.88 km2)
column4: of which 7.66 square miles (19.84 km2) is land and 0.40 square miles (1.04 km2) is water.The city is divided into the North Side and South Side by the Fox River
column5: which is spanned by four bridges.

column1: Kaukauna is located at the intersections of several major roads. Interstate 41
column2: which forms the backbone of the Fox Cities' transit network
column3: runs along the northern edge of the city and intersects Wisconsin Highway 55
column5: and two county roads that serve as major thoroughfares in the city. US 10 is just to the south of Kaukauna
column6: and Wisconsin Highway 441 is just to the west. Kaukauna is a member of Valley Transit
column7: which provides bus service. Kaukauna is served by Appleton International Airport for airport service.

column1: The city has diverse industrial and manufacturing businesses
column2: including the Oscar Thilmany Paper Mill
column3: constructed in 1883.  The name dropped off the mill when it was purchased by HammerMill in 1969
column4: which was in turn bought by International Paper in 1986.In 2005
column5: New York-based equity firm Kohlberg & Company bought the mill
column6: changed the name back to Thilmany
column7: and created a company of the same name. It is now owned by KPS Capital Partners
column8: and was renamed Expera Specialty Solutions in 2013. In 2018

column1: Kaukauna is served by the Kaukauna Area School District
